awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Integration of metabolic cues and life cycle decisions in Chlamydomonas
awd_abstract_narration:
Single-celled organisms, such as protists and bacteria, inhabit fluctuating environments where nutrient availability isn't always guaranteed. To cope with this "feast or famine" uncertainty, cells have evolved processes that allow them to respond appropriately by growing and dividing when nutrients are present (proliferation), or by becoming dormant and adopting an energy-conserving state when starved (quiescence). This project utilizes a single-celled reference organism, the green alga Chlamydomonas, to investigate how molecular switches that govern proliferation and quiescence are controlled and how they are coordinated to ensure that they don't interfere with each other. Microorganisms like these can accumulate large quantities of valuable compounds, e.g. oils, but only when starved. It is anticipated that knowledge about the molecular switches governing transitions between the states of proliferation and quiescence will allow predictions about how these states can be controlled and engineered. Thus, newly discovered details about these molecular switches provide potential engineering strategies to uncouple high yields of valuable compounds from starvation responses. Students and postdoctoral fellows from the two research locations will collaborate to identify and model the interactions between key regulators of quiescence and proliferation that have counterparts in many other species including plants and animals. The diversity of approaches and quantitative training components prepare the trainees for science careers in industry or academia. 

The long term goal of this project is to gain a predictive understanding of how nutrient and metabolic cues are integrated into coherent decisions that control life cycle state transitions. In the unicellular green alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, two nuclear protein complexes, CHT7-C and RB-C, have been identified that govern the transitions between nutrient-deprivation induced quiescence, cell growth, and commitment to cell division. It is hypothesized that the quiescence regulator CHT7-C, and the cell cycle commitment regulator RB-C form an interlocking transcriptional network that coordinately controls cell growth and division responses to nutrient or metabolic cues. The objectives of this project are to: (1) characterize purified CHT7-C and RB-C complexes in order to define their subunit composition and modifications under different life cycle states; (2) Identify CHT7-C and RB-C target genes followed by generation of a transcriptional network model to observe common nodes that functionally couple the two complexes; (3) combine mutations affecting different components of the two complexes into isogenic lines to obtain synthetic phenotypes that provide insights into function and interrelation of the two complexes in vivo; and (4) build a testable logic switch model and develop quantitative markers to test and revise the model. The collaborative approach taken for studying the interactions between quiescence and cell proliferation regulators is aimed at transforming the understanding of the networks that establish and maintain coordinated global responses to metabolic and nutritional cues.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: A key decision in the life of a unicellular organism such as a microalga is whether to divide and grow, or to enter a resting stage to wait out unfavorable conditions. Nutrient availability is one of the cues affecting this decision. Understanding the mechanism of how microalgae decide to stop growing following nutrient deprivation and to resume growth following nutrient resupply is the long-term goal of this project.

Focusing on the model alga Chlamydomonas, a functional analysis of a key protein, CHT7 (Compromised in the Hydrolysis of Triacylglycerol 7), involved in the regulation of nutrient-dependent regulation of the cell division cycle was conducted. The phenotype of a Chlamydomonas mutant lacking this protein was characterized in detail in different genetic backgrounds. In addition, the CHT7 protein itself and its presence in a protein complex were investigated in detail. This study led to the following conclusions:

1. Cells lacking CHT7 can grow normally in the presence of nutrients but increasingly lose their viability during nitrogen (N) deprivation and struggle to regrow and degrade their storage lipids (hence the name) when N is refed. Individual cells show abnormal growth and division following N resupply after N deprivation, and only a small number of cells can form colonies.

2. Extensive transcriptome analysis of cht7 mutant cells indicates a general derepression of genes compared to the wild type, which is most severe during N deprivation. Notably, a distinct subset of genes involved in the progression of the cell cycle that would normally be down-regulated following N deprivation remains active. This result was consistent with abnormal cell and growth phenotypes and led to the hypothesis that CHT7 formally acts as a repressor of cell cycle genes during N deprivation to allow cells to enter a resting state under these conditions.

3. The CHT7 protein is present in a large protein complex. One of the most surprising findings was that its predicted DNA binding domain is dispensable for function. However, its predicted protein interaction domains are essential. It was concluded that CHT7 must interact with transcription factors and serves as a scaffolding protein in a protein complex to exert is gene-repressing function. Identifying these transcription factors will be the next step in the mechanistic exploration of nutrient-dependent cell cycle regulation in Chlamydomonas.

4. The relationship between CHT7 and a known key protein involved in cell cycle regulation in Chlamydomonas, the retinoblastoma like protein MAT3, was investigated. The bulk of both proteins is present in two distinct complexes. However, CHT7 and MAT3 were found together in less abundant or less stable protein complexes suggesting they can directly interact.

5. The CHT7 protein is phosphorylated and its phosphorylation state during the cell cycle changes as does its abundance. Reducing prominent phosphorylation sites of CHT7 reduced the phosphorylation level of the protein but did not impair its functionality. Identifying and altering additional phosphorylation sites will be key to understanding the functional relevance CHT7 phosphorylation.

6. Based on the combined findings mentioned, a refined model/hypothesis for the function of the CHT7 containing complex in nutrient-dependent cell cycle regulation was developed.

Broader Impacts: Microalgae are widely explored to produce biofuels and other useful compounds. They will produce high levels of energy-rich storage lipids when deprived of nutrients. The same treatment will send these microalgae into a resting state and biomass production ceases. To overcome this conundrum and limitation of productivity with future bioengineering approaches, it will be essential to understand the mechanisms of how microalgal cells enter and exit a nutrient deprivation induced resting state, the focus of this study. Moreover, understanding how cell division is controlled in response to the metabolic state of a cell promises to provide key insights into diseases such as cancer, where cells divide untethered from feedback provided by different cues. The microalgal system developed here and the insights gained into the function of the CHT7 protein provide a facile model and starting point to study in general the control of cell division in response to nutrient availability and metabolic state of a cell.

The project has provided training opportunities for five undergraduate students, two graduate students, and one postdoctoral researcher. In addition, a Professor Emerita was involved providing additional mentoring of the junior researchers on the project. One graduate student completed her PhD thesis and moved on to work in the biotech industry, a second PhD student is expected to graduate shortly. Of the undergraduate students, three are now pursuing PhDs. The postdoctoral researcher has entered a career as instructor teaching biosciences courses to undergraduate students.

In addition, an algal growth incubator was developed to grow cells synchronously for cell cycle studies of wild type and mutant populations.
